title: Hollinsclough Walks

images.title: Jonathan Clitheroe / Hollinsclough pictured against the backdrop of Chrome Hill
images.caption: Hollinsclough pictured against the backdrop of Chrome Hill. This picture is taken from an ancient sunken track which drops down into Hollinclough from the west. The Methodist Chapel (dated 1801) is visible to the left and the old school house can be made out behind the trees to the right of shot. The majestic contours of Chrome Hill form an imposing backdrop.

images.title: Dave Dunford / Hitter Hill from Parkhouse Hill
images.caption: Hitter Hill from Parkhouse Hill. View eastwards from the summit of Parkhouse Hill. Glutton Grange is visible to the left of the ridge in the foreground.

images.title: Descending Chrome Hill by Jonathan Clitheroe, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Descending Chrome Hill

images.title: Hollins Farm from Chrome Hill by Neil Theasby, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Hollins Farm from Chrome Hill

description: This Peak District village is located in a fine spot for scenic walks in the National Park. This circular walk from the village takes you up to the splendid viewpoints on Parkhouse Hill and Chrome Hill which lie just to the east of the settlement. You'll also pass Hollins Hill on the northern side of the village. Along the way there are wonderful views over the National Park and some photogenic limeston rock formations to admire. To continue your walking in the area head west onto Axe Edge Moor and you could visit one of the major local highlights at Three Shires Head. Here you will find an ancient packhorse bridge located at the point where the counties of Cheshire, Derbyshire and Staffordshire meet.
